Uganda recently completed a National TB Prevalence Survey. The Survey revealed that Uganda’s TB and TB/HIV burden are much higher than previously estimated. However, national program data indicates a declining trend in TB case notification over the last several years. According to the MOH, an estimated 45,000 TB cases remain undiagnosed on an annual basis, of which 16,028 are TB/HIV co-infected. In response to this evidence, the MOH recently revised the National Strategic Plan to focus on finding these missing TB and TB/HIV cases. As part of this effort, the National Strategic Plan states that GeneXpert MTB/Rif is the test of first choice for all presumptive TB cases for facilities that have a GeneXpert machine. For facilities without GeneXpert, the revised national TB diagnostic algorithm prioritizes using the national referral and sample transportation system to send sputum samples for HIV patients, children, pregnant women, and other risk groups to laboratories with GeneXpert.
The national referral and sample transportation system in Uganda is built around 100 hubs with capacity to run diagnostic tests for HIV and TB/HIV. Of these 100 hubs, only 77 have a GeneXpert machine on site, leaving 23 hubs without machines. Under this mechanism, PEPFAR Uganda will support the Uganda Stop TB Partnership (USTP), through the Global Drug Facility, to procure and fast track 16 GeneXpert machines for 16 high volume hubs. PEPFAR Uganda will coordinate with other donors to plan procurement of machines for the remaining 7 hubs.
